Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Inference for Biomedical Big Data: Theory, Methods, and Tools
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the workshop "Statistical Inference for Biomedical Big Data: Theory, Methods, and Tools" to be held on the Gainesville campus of the University of Florida, Gainesville, Florida on April 7-8, 2017. Dramatic improvements in data collection and acquisition technologies in the past two decades have enabled scientists to collect vast amounts of health-related data in biomedical studies. If analyzed properly, these data can expand our knowledge and improve contemporary healthcare services from diagnosis to prevention to personalized treatment, and can also provide insights into reducing healthcare costs. However, biomedical data can be rather big and complex, and are often characterized by some mixture of high dimensionality, heterogeneity, high volume, high velocity, and high variety. Advances in biomedical big data analysis can greatly impact the development of biomedical sciences.

This workshop will bring together some of the most prominent statisticians in biomedical big data and a selected group of local biomedical researchers in a collaborative setting to discuss and foster cutting-edge developments of statistical theory, methods, and tools for biomedical big data analysis. The format of this workshop is designed to foster interactions between statisticians and biomedical researchers. To facilitate communications between graduate students, junior researchers, and senior researchers, a poster session is included in the program. To disseminate the results of the meeting, the program and abstracts will be widely circulated, and modest travel funds for a large geographically diverse group of graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty are planned. More information about the workshop can be found at http://biostat.ufl.edu/seminars/biostatistics-workshop/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of the award, we have successfully hosted the workshop "Statistical Inference for Biomedical Big Data" in the Gainesville campus of The University of Florida on April 7 and 8, 2017.  The organization committe includes Drs. Somnath Datta, Faming Liang, Peihua Qiu, and Fei Zou. Some detailed information about the workshop can be found at  http://biostat.ufl.edu/seminars/biostatistics-workshop/.

The workshop attrtaced over 70 participants, including professors, postdocs and graduate students,  from different universities of the United States. The workshop consisted of 28 talks given by the leading experts in the reasearch area, which have covered cutting-edge developments of statistical theory and methods for a variety of types of biomedical big data. For example, Dr. George Michailidis talked about  sparse network modeling for the analysis of large-scale metabolomics data, Dr. Wei Sun talked about mapping gene expression QTL of impure tumor samples, and Dr. Mingyao Li talked about modeling allele-specific gene expression by single-cell RNA sequencing data. While some other speakers focused on more general statistical theory or methodology for high-dimensional or big data inference. For example, Dr. Lingzhou Xue talked about the theory on high-dimensional tests, Dr. Qi Long talked about Bayesian variable selection for structured high-dimensional data, and Dr. Yi Li talked about classification with ultrahigh-dimensional features. We noted that due to the weather reason, a lot of flights to Atlanta and around airports were canceled on April 6 and 7, 2017, and as a result, some speakers had to cancel their trip. The spots for the canceled talks were filled by local colleagues. 

The workshop also consisted of a poster session presented by the graduate students and postdoc from different universities of the United States. Based on the papers and posters submitted prior to the workshop, the organization committee selected four students/postdocs for the travel award and three students/postdocs for the paper award.

The workshop has provided an excellent platform for the development of new statistical theory and methodology for biomedical big data as well as interdisciplinary interactions, inspired new ideas for biomedical research, and increased visibility of the biostatics department of The University of Florida.


Last Modified: 06/29/2018
Modified by: Faming Liang
